title: Founders of Bankrupt Startup UBiome Indicted in Fraud Case
summary: Grand jury charges Drs. Jessica Richman and Zac Apte, who have faced scrutiny over billing practices. The former co-chief executives of bankrupt lab-testing startup uBiome Inc. were charged with healthcare and securities fraud among other offenses, in an indictment handed up by a federal grand jury in San Francisco.

title: Peloton CEO Says Child Died in Treadmill Accident
summary: Fitness-machine maker says it is aware of 'small handful' of cases where children have been hurt; federal consumer watchdog says it has opened investigation. A child was killed in an accident involving a Peloton Interactive Inc. treadmill, the fitness equipment maker's chief executive officer said in a letter posted online for customers.

title: For FedEx, Covid-19 Pandemic Keeps Delivering Profit
summary: Package volumes rose 25% in Ground unit handling e-commerce surge. FedEx Corp.'s quarterly profit nearly tripled and revenue jumped 23%, despite winter storms in the U.S. that disrupted its delivery operations and sapped its profit by $350 million.

title: Andrew Cuomo Plots His Survival
summary: Under scandal's cloud and impeachment's threat, New York's governor decides not to go quietly.. We're seeing some Grade A, first-class, brass-knuckle politics in the state of New York. Wednesday there was an event in Harlem ostensibly to publicize a pop-up vaccination clinic at Mount Neboh Baptist Church, where the embattled governor, Andrew Cuomo, was vaccinated (the Johnson & Johnson one-shot). It was really a planned and raucous rally for a governor under impeachment threat and accused of sexual harassment and nursing-home deaths.

title: 'Assignment Russia' Review: Murrow's Man in Moscow
summary: Khrushchev called the 6-foot-3 Marvin Kalb 'Peter the Great'-and in Paris shared croissants with the CBS reporter.. Roger Mudd ascended to Network News Heaven at 93 last week. There he was reunited with Walter Cronkite, John Chancellor, Douglas Edwards, Howard K. Smith, Edward R. Murrow and other luminaries. Still with us are old hands Dan Rather, Diane Sawyer, Bernard Shaw, and the Kalb brothers, Marvin and Bernard-living witnesses to the days when TV news was more serious business and less partisan gasbaggery.

title: Raising the Minimum Wage Will Definitely Cost Jobs
summary: A survey of the economics research shows the likelihood of a substantial reduction in employment.. A recent Congressional Budget Office report estimated that 1.4 million jobs would be lost if a new $15 federal minimum wage is signed into law. Advocates were quick to dismiss the CBO's conclusion. "It is not a stretch to say that a new consensus has emerged among economists that minimum wage increases have raised wages without substantial job loss," saidHeidi Shierholz of the Economic Policy Institute, which has also circulated a letter signed by economics Nobel laureates and others making the same claim.

title: Life During Wartime, Before FaceTime
summary: The pandemic has separated families. Our grandparents were there before.. Each generation, when forced by unforeseen circumstances to be physically separated from loved ones, finds a way to let them know how much they are missed.

title: A Day in a Scorched-Earth Senate
summary: Democrats want to 'fix' the chamber by ending the filibuster. That would break it.. The Democrat-media complex reserves a special scorn for politicians who burst their bubbles. So little wonder that cabal is dumping so hard this week on Senate Republican Leader Mitch McConnell. How dare he speak truth to filibuster nonsense?

title: Pope Francis' Mosul Moment
summary: There has never been a papal trip quite like the holy father's visit to Iraq this month.. Aboard the Papal Plane

title: Boeing Moon Rocket Passes NASA Test
summary: Engines for Artemis mission complete eight-minute run, paving way for lunar flight this year. NASA's plans for a lunar mission this year remain on track after it said a deep-space rocket made by Boeing Co. passed a key engine test on Thursday.

title: Toyota Disclosed Thai Bribery Probe to U.S. Authorities
summary: The car maker reported the possible violations to the Justice Department and the Securities and Exchange Commission in April 2020, according to an SEC filing. Toyota Motor Corp. said on Thursday that it alerted the U.S. Department of Justice and the Securities and Exchange Commission to possible antibribery violations involving a subsidiary in Thailand.

title: The Tax Cut Ban and the Constitution
summary: Ohio sues to overturn Congress's takeover of the states' fiscal policy.. Democrats didn't flip a single state legislative chamber or governor's mansion in the 2020 election, while Republicans flipped three. Yet through their Covid bill Democrats are trying to partially nullify these election results by mandating that state governments cannot pass tax cuts as a condition of receiving aid. Ohio on Wednesday sued the Treasury to enjoin the mandate, and the case is an early test of progressive ambitions to upset the constitutional balance.

title: Earmarks Are the GOP's Bridge to Nowhere
summary: Republicans sign on to the Democrats' pork-barrel revival.. As Democrats pushed through their $1.9 trillion spending bill, Republicans lamented the largesse for political interest groups and pointed to mounting federal debt. Yet on Wednesday the House GOP voted in a secret ballot, 102-84, to resurrect legislative earmarks.

title: The Securities and Politics Commission
summary: The woke agenda is about to redefine financial regulation.. The Securities and Exchange Commission has by and large maintained a reputation as an apolitical protector of investors. That may change as Democrats gear up to use even the SEC as a cudgel to impose their political and cultural agenda on corporate America.

title: The Pension Bailouts Begin
summary: Congress spends $86 billion to rescue multi-employer retirement funds with no demands for reform.. Democrats left no liberal interest group behind in their $1.9 trillion spending bill this month. That includes private unions whose ailing multi-employer pension plans will get an $86 billion rescue. This is the first of many such air-drops to come.

title: NFL Deals Bring Thursday Football to Amazon, Super Bowl to ABC
summary: The league's new long-term pacts feed streaming services, valued at more than $100 billion. The National Football League unveiled long-term media deals that people familiar with the matter said are valued at over $100 billion, providing a windfall for the league and significantly expanding the availability of games on streaming platforms.

title: Neil deGrasse Tyson: Science Needs Better Marketing
summary: Many people who love their high-tech smartphones refused to trust scientists when it came to Covid.. I learned that when faced with a common enemy-an enemy of the entire human species-we regressed to basal, primitive instincts rather than band together to fight. This was a test run for an alien invasion, and we failed. I had naively hoped that the same tribal urges that pit human against human could be harnessed to pit all humans against the killer virus. But that did not happen.

title: The Unforgiven
summary: Teen Vogue announces the cancellation of the day.. Some say that being a progressive leftist means never having to say you accept that someone is sorry. But what about accepting a person's expression of regret for hurtful comments and then having second thoughts? The cancellation of the day comes to you courtesy of publishing firm Condé Nast and occurs at one of its most esteemed titles, Teen Vogue.

summary: A global container shortage and congestion in U.S. ports delayed inventory by more than three weeks in latest quarter. Nike Inc. joined a growing list of U.S. companies getting squeezed by global supply-chain disruptions stemming from the Covid-19 pandemic.

summary: Parents reported struggles balancing work and parenting, and some said their children's mental and emotional health had worsened. Parents whose children received virtual instruction were more likely to report poorer well-being for themselves and their kids, a federal government survey found.

Burns, on a voice vote after a Republican senator lifted a hold on the nomination that had forced a two-week delay.

summary: The deal values Relativity at about $3.6 billion and will make Silver Lake its largest shareholder. Private-equity firm Silver Lake is making a big investment in legal-and-compliance technology company Relativity ODA LLC, the companies said.

summary: Benchmark 10-year note trades up above 1.7% for the first time since Covid-19 pandemic began. Selling in U.S. government bonds accelerated on Thursday, sending yields soaring again as uncertainty over the pace of economic expansion continued to unsettle financial markets.

Oil prices fell more than 7% on Thursday, recording their biggest one-day drop since September as traders weighed signs that demand in Europe could falter and data showing that crude remains plentiful.

title: How to Manage Up at Work
summary: Most Popular News. If you have ever had a difficult boss, you are not alone. According to a 2019 survey of 2,800 workers by staffing firm Robert Half, about half of respondents had quit a job because of a bad manager. But whether your manager is difficult or supportive, your working days may be improved if you learn how to manage up and adapt your behavior to suit your boss's work style.

title: Tourists Trickle Back to New York City
summary: Hotels see an uptick in occupancy rates as Covid-19 quarantine restrictions are set to ease. Justus Dillon, a resident of Hattiesburg, Miss., had never been to New York City before. But she recently decided to join a friend for a first-ever trip.

title: Unemployed Workers Likely Won't Need to Amend Returns for Tax Break
summary: IRS Commissioner Charles Rettig says officials hope to make a formal announcement 'in the near future'. WASHINGTON-Unemployed workers likely won't need to file amended tax returns to take advantage of a new federal tax exemption for jobless benefits, the head of the Internal Revenue Service said Thursday.

title: Tech Shares Extend Decline as Bond Yields Rise
summary: Investors sell government bonds after jobless claims rise and Fed pledges to maintain easy-money policies. U.S. stocks fell Thursday as shares of technology companies and other high-growth stocks succumbed to another selloff in the government bond market.

title: U.K. Prosecutors Close KBR Bribery Probe
summary: Evidence didn't meet threshold for prosecution, U.K's Serious Fraud Office says. The U.K.'s major economic crimes agency on Thursday said it had closed a bribery-related probe into subsidiaries of U.S. engineering firm KBR Inc.

title: U.S. Must Fabricate High-End Chips Again
summary: We can turn the tide, but it will require the U.S. government leveling the global playing field by investing boldly in domestic chip-manufacturing incentives and advanced research.. Your editorial "The Semiconductor Shortage" (March 13) is right that government action is not needed to correct the short-term supply-demand imbalance causing the global chip shortage, but wrong that the U.S. can "prod" its way to stronger domestic semiconductor production and more secure chip supply chains in the long term. Global competitors haven't passed the U.S. as a location for chip manufacturing by prodding. They've done it by funding ambitious government incentives to lure semiconductor production to their shores.

title: Trade Union Movement Is Ever More Political
summary: The primary objective of the AFL-CIO is to increase the American workers' collective bargaining power through political action.. Maxford Nelsen's "Unions and Democrats Attack the Right to Work" (op-ed, March 12) on the passage of the PRO Act in the House of Representatives tells what's happening but doesn't tell why. We only need read the significant changes in the direction by the unions in the 2017 AFL-CIO's new constitutional preamble that emphasizes the labor movement's priority for political action over collective bargaining in a way previous AFL-CIO constitutions did not. We can see the result of this paradigm shift in the AFL-CIO's Commission on the Future of Work and Unions in its 2019 report and the integration of these stated objectives in the 2020 Democratic Party platform to complete the fusion with the party.

title: Remembering the Old Barbizon's Glory Days
summary: The plainness of the room provided a distraction-free canvas for creating the dreams you hoped would unfold.. Regarding Heller McAlpin's engaging review of the book "The Barbizon" by Paulina Bren (Books, Feb. 27): I stayed at the Barbizon as a 16-year-old during the summer of 1969. The plainness of the room provided a distraction-free canvas for creating the dreams you hoped would unfold in the city that awaited beyond the Barbizon's elaborate but secure walls.

title: Putin Responds Icily After Biden Says He Considers Russian Leader a Killer
summary: A day after Moscow recalled its ambassador, Putin said the U.S. should recognize its own shortcomings. MOSCOW-Russian President Vladimir Putin responded icily to President Biden the day after he said he considered the Russian leader a killer, as a barrage of criticism from the Russian government threatened to put more pressure on already strained ties between Moscow and Washington.

title: The Sociology of That Addictive Junk Food
summary: It would be more accurate to say that when women joined the workforce, there was no ensuing redistribution of cooking duties in many homes.. I disagree with at least one of author Michael Moss's assertions cited in Matthew Rees's review of "Hooked" (Bookshelf, March 12). Mr. Moss writes that part of the reason the obesity rate in the U.S. has risen to 42.4% is: "When women moved into the workplace . . . there was less time at home to devote to cooking." It would be more accurate to say that when women joined the workforce, there was no ensuing redistribution of cooking duties in many homes. This would assign responsibility for the lack of home-cooking more accurately-to working men and women.

title: Republicans Need to Face the Issues Raised by H.R. 1
summary: Whatever the demerits of H.R. 1, it is indisputably about expanding access to the ballot box, and the question Republicans must answer is why this is a bad thing.. Regarding Kimberley A. Strassel's "Democrats Sell Out Their States" (Potomac Watch, March 5): Whatever the demerits of H.R.1, including its kitchen-sink approach to legislation, it is indisputably about expanding access to the ballot box, and the question Republicans must answer is why this is a bad thing. Her answer isn't that such expanded and more uniform access would increase the risk of voter fraud as compared with the current hodgepodge of state laws, but rather that it would "rig the game for a permanent Democratic majority." But if having more people cast votes really means that Republicans will lose more elections, shouldn't they be examining why this is so and formulating policies that appeal to more voters, rather than fighting what appears to be a rear-guard battle against majority rule? Every fair election is "rigged" in the absurdly narrow sense that the preferences of the majority will dictate its outcome. Would we have it any other way? The people select their legislators; legislators don't get to decide who constitutes "the people."

title: After Death of Covid-Denying President, Tanzania May Pivot Pandemic Policy
summary: Leader of East African nation told residents to turn to religion to beat the virus; country set to swear in first female president. KAMPALA Uganda-The death of John Magufuli, Tanzania's strongman president who urged citizens to gather in churches and mosques to beat Covid-19, has rocked East Africa but raised hopes that a government that became the continent's chief skeptic on the virus and vaccines will change course.

title: 'The Courier' Review: Staid Secrets
summary: Benedict Cumberbatch stars as an unassuming British businessman turned undercover operative in the Soviet Union during the Cuban Missile Crisis. It is not a good sign when a film keeps evoking superior examples of its genre. And a worse sign still when the genre itself seems more remote from current concerns than it deserves to be. Such is the case with "The Courier," opening in theaters, an earnest spy thriller based on a true story and set in the early 1960s, at the height of the Cold War. Benedict Cumberbatch is Greville Wynne, a British civilian recruited by MI6 and the CIA to travel to Moscow and make covert contact with Oleg Penkovsky (Merab Ninidze), a Soviet military intelligence colonel who wants to help the West avoid a shooting war. Both performances are expert, and Mr. Cumberbatch clearly suffered for his art in order to portray the terrible punishment his character endured. But this story of intersecting destinies is oddly self-miniaturizing, its drama dwarfed for a long stretch of time by the titanic significance of events playing out off-screen.

title: 'The Last Five Years' and 'The Aran Islands' Reviews: Making the Most of Streaming Theater
summary: Jason Robert Brown's 2001 musical, inventively filmed in a New York apartment; Joe O'Byrne's one-man play based on the diary entries of J.M. Synge, enhanced by footage of the titular Irish isles.. The most consequential development in the postmodern history of the musical has been the explosion of interest in small-scale revivals initially triggered by John Doyle's 2005 Broadway production of "Sweeney Todd." What we have not yet seen is a comparable explosion of newly written "chamber musicals" that, like Jason Robert Brown's "The Last Five Years" (2001) and Josh Schmidt's "A Minister's Wife" (2009), are written for very small casts and accompanied by instrumental ensembles of like size. Since such shows would be well suited to the daunting problems posed by the Covid-19 pandemic, it is good news that "The Last Five Years," a two-actor musical, is now being presented as a webcast production of supreme dramatic and technical excellence, as fine a show of any kind as I've reviewed since I started covering online theater a year ago.

title: Town & Country (Friday Crossword, March 19)
'Enforcement' Review: Mutually Assured Hostility
summary: Two Danish cops find themselves in danger after an incident of police brutality outrages the Muslim community they patrol. All policing, like all politics, is local. The Danish cops in "Enforcement" know the perils of their turf, a crowded suburban ghetto, and the Muslim immigrants who live there know them and their tough tactics all too well. Yet the film lays claim to wider significance when an unseen suspect in custody, Talib Ben Hassi, is heard to cry "I can't breathe," and shortly thereafter word of his death comes over the radio.

title: New York City, State Disagree Over Reopenings
summary: City officials say governor is moving too fast and jeopardizing progress made against Covid-19 at critical moment. New York City officials expressed frustration Thursday over not being consulted by state officials on reopening decisions that may affect the spread of Covid-19, while officials in Albany announced plans to loosen restrictions on outdoor sports arenas.

title: 2021 Subaru Legacy: Too Slow to Evolve?
summary: Subaru re-engineered its Legacy sedan while preserving its outmoded look. Dan Neil breaks down the good and the bad of the brand's decision to cater to its highly loyal, change-resistant fan base.. WHEN IT COMES to Subaru , the world cleaves in two: those who have and those who haven't. If you have ever had a Subaru as your mobility helpmate, statistics show you are disposed to buy another-owner loyalty is among the highest of mass-market brands. The company's full-time all-wheel drive system and horizontally opposed engine (assuring low center of gravity) is unique; and it is, by a comfortable margin, the best way to put torque to all four wheels, short of electrification.

title: Armenia-Azerbaijan War: What is Happening in Nagorno-Karabakh?
summary: Armenia leader calls a snap parliamentary election in a bid to quash political turmoil after the nation's loss of parts of Nagorno-Karabakh enclave to Azerbaijan. The fallout from last year's brief but bloody conflict between Armenia and Azerbaijan over the disputed region of Nagorno-Karabakh continued to reverberate more than four months after a Russian-brokered ceasefire halted the fighting in the South Caucasus.

title: Ron DeSantis: Don't Trust the Elites
summary: Influential people in public health, government and the media failed to rise to the moment. The Covid-19 pandemic represented a test of elites in the U.S., from public-health experts to the corporate media. The results have been disappointing. Policy makers who bucked the elites and challenged the narrative have been proven right to do so.

title: Covid-19 Variant Vaccines in Works at J&J
summary: The company, which recently launched a Covid-19 vaccine, is probing booster shots and new vaccines in case they are needed to tackle elusive virus variants. Johnson & Johnson is working on several next-generation versions of its Covid-19 vaccine that may be needed to bolster protection against some of the coronavirus variants that have emerged.

title: Dollar Stores Deserve a Break
summary: Dollar General gave muted guidance for 2021, but there are plenty of tailwinds that should help its main customer base. What a year dollar stores have had.

title: AstraZeneca Vaccine's Woes in Europe Aren't Hurting Its Appeal Elsewhere
summary: The low-cost Covid-19 shot remains the most widely used of the Western front-runners and is seen as crucial for developing countries. In the European Union, vaccine skepticism, contradictory statements by governments and reports of adverse reactions have eroded trust in the shot developed by AstraZeneca PLC and University of Oxford, delaying an inoculation campaign that was already proceeding at a glacial pace.

title: Two Mortgage Titans Are in a Brawl. The Winner Is Michigan State Basketball.
summary: Billionaire alums battle each other for business, but both support the Spartans who play in the NCAA tournament tonight. Call it a different kind of March Madness.

summary: Bottlenecks in Southern California are easing, but U.S. West Coast ports expect a surge in container shipments to continue. Logjams at U.S. ports are spreading beyond Southern California's choked gateways, and shipping officials are projecting the backups will continue into the summer.

summary: In Washington state, a 750-square-foot space built for sports equipment now doubles as a home. We are delighted that you'd like to resume your subscription.

title: A Washington Couple Built a Gear Loft to Stash Sports Equipment. Now They Practically Live There
summary: Resume Subscription. In 2017, Leslie Garrard and Heidi Durham, both 48, decided they were spending enough time in Eastern Washington's Methow Valley that they wanted a place to store all their sports equipment, including multiple skis, bikes, kayaks and paddle boards. They bought a five-acre lot for $225,000 in Winthrop, Wash.

title: Chat Startup Discord Hires Its First Finance Chief to Boost Growth
summary: Tomasz Marcinkowski joined the company from Pinterest. Chat service Discord Inc. has hired its first finance chief, a move that comes after a year of pandemic-fueled growth in users and revenue.

title: Congress Sowed the Seeds of Jan. 6 in 1887
summary: The Electoral Vote Count Act lets Congress think it can choose the President, but it's unconstitutional.. Congress plans to establish a commission to investigate the Jan. 6 storming of the Capitol. We already know one reason for that terrible event. Members of the mob acted in the mistaken belief, encouraged by President Trump, that lawmakers had the power to determine the election's winner. Congress itself sowed the seeds of this belief when it passed the Electoral Vote Count Act of 1887 and could destroy it root and branch by repealing that law.

title: India Beats China at Vaccine Diplomacy
summary: But New Delhi's massive success is a function of collaboration with the West, not 'self-reliance.'. When it comes to bullet trains, manufacturing plants and Olympic medals, China regularly eats India's lunch. But the South Asian nation is proving competitive with its East Asian rival in one important area: vaccine diplomacy.

title: U.S. Joins Russia in Calling on Kabul, Taliban to Speed Up Power-Sharing Talks
summary: International efforts to end fighting in Afghanistan are intensifying ahead of a May 1 deadline for the full withdrawal of U.S. troops. Four countries including the U.S. called on the Afghan government and the Taliban to reduce violence and begin discussions on sharing power, in a fresh effort to end the two-decade war as a deadline for the full withdrawal of American troops draws closer.

title: Las Vegas, After Its Latest Bust, Aims for Another Boom
summary: The gambling and entertainment capital's dependence on tourism and crowds made it vulnerable to a major economic hit during Covid-19 shutdowns, yet it's keeping the focus on that 'core competency'. Nearby, a few people leaned over a craps table, the thrill of the game replaced by quiet study as the dice rolled.

title: Salted Honey Chopped Liver
summary: Jake Cohen's chopped liver balances tradition with an of-the-moment, sweet-salty flavor profile. Honey and caramelized onions sweeten the dish and cut the richness, too.. To explore and search through all our recipes, check out the new WSJ Recipes page.

title: A Passover-Ready Recipe From Tiktok's 'Modern Mensch'
summary: New cookbook 'Jew-ish' contains recipes both creative and culturally rooted. Author Jake Cohen dishes on maximalist entertaining, go-to utensils and those infernal sprinkle-bomb cakes.. PUMPKIN-SPICE BABKA. Shakshuka alla vodka. Challah panzanella. According to Jake Cohen, these recipes qualify as "Jew-ish." This month, Mr. Cohen, 27, a food writer and gregarious social media star with a devoted following on Instagram and TikTok, unleashes the notion on the world in "Jew-ish: A Cookbook: Reinvented Recipes From a Modern Mensch" (Houghton Mifflin Harcourt). Published just in time for Passover, it's Mr. Cohen's personal, uniquely millennial interpretation of Jewish cuisine, including the Ashkenazi dishes he grew up with, the Persian- and Iraqi-Jewish recipes that he learned from his in-laws, and the foods that simply capture his imagination.

title: For Wealthy New York Buyers, Small Apartments Aren't Cutting It Anymore
summary: As the market recovers from a Covid slowdown, well-heeled homebuyers are spending millions to upgrade their spaces. Soon Jang, a California-based physicist, and his wife, Laurel Jang, began eyeing apartments in New York last spring for their youngest son, who was slated to attend Columbia University in the fall. They quickly settled on a roughly $2.3 million two-bedroom property at the Vandewater, a new development in the Morningside Heights area of Manhattan near the college, and put down a deposit to buy it sight unseen.

Goldman Sachs Group Inc. is talking to JetBlue Airways Corp. about taking over its credit-card program, according to people familiar with the matter, the latest effort from the Wall Street firm to push deeper into consumer finance.

title: How Israel Delivered the World's Fastest Vaccine Rollout
summary: Resume Subscription. TEL AVIV-In the world's fastest coronavirus vaccine rollout to date, Israel has given at least one shot to nearly 60% of its residents, a feat propelled by an ample supply of doses and an uncommon healthcare system that combines competition with tax-funded universal coverage.

title: Jennifer Doudna: The Power of Mission-Driven Science
summary: Professors, researchers and engineers set aside their own projects to focus on how best to fight the pandemic. The pandemic year has been marked by so much tragedy, but I am heartened by what scientific innovation and collaboration have achieved to help move our society forward.

title: Google to Invest $7 Billion in Bet on Post-Pandemic Office
summary: Tech giant says 'coming together' is core to its culture in announcing U.S. investment. Google says it is doubling down on the office.

MOSCOW-Armenia's prime minister called a snap parliamentary election in an attempt to quell tensions that have led to demands for his resignation following the country's loss of swaths of the Nagorno-Karabakh enclave to Azerbaijan in last year's brief but bloody war.

title: How Deal Making Caught Up With Lex Greensill
summary: Greensill Capital's founder pitched deals to finance a nuclear submarine and investments tied to the hajj. Lex Greensill's company was in the staid business of matching risk-averse investors with safe, short-term loans. Mr. Greensill, though, was a deal maker who often preferred more complicated investments in speculative ventures.

title: What We Lose When We Don't See Our Work Acquaintances
summary: They aren't close friends. But daily chats and check-ins with colleagues can help alleviate loneliness and boost well-being more than many people realize.. I miss Shawn. Before the pandemic, he worked just down the hall. Like me, he preferred working in the office rather than at home. And like me, he loved listening to post-punk music, riffing about politics, and brewing an afternoon espresso. Although few of our conversations lasted more than 10 minutes, for nearly every workday for 12 years, Shawn was part of the social fabric of my work life.

title: World-Wide Streaming Subscriptions Pass One Billion
summary: Mass movie theater closures caused global box-office revenue to drop more than $30 billion in 2020, Motion Picture Association says. The number of subscriptions to online video streaming services around the world reached 1.1 billion in 2020, according to data released by the Motion Picture Association on Thursday-a new milestone marked amid the Covid-19 pandemic that kept people locked down, seeking their entertainment at home.

title: U.S. Jobless Claims Hover Near Pandemic Lows
summary: Worker filings for benefits have eased since the start of the year. February's winter storm could have affected recent claims.. Worker filings for jobless benefits are hovering near the pandemic's lowest levels, adding to evidence of recent economic improvement.

summary: Moves comes as Swiss bank seeks to recoup money for investors in its troubled supply-chain finance funds. title: Petco Revenue Jumps in First Earnings Report After Going Public
summary: Pet-store operator cites surge in pet ownership during the pandemic and logistics shift. summary: What to expect, should you ever have to make the daring descent.

title: Door Man
summary: Bobby Sager of Boston bought dozens of doors from the Chelsea Hotel to hang in his Boston triplex. He plans other artistic ventures around the pieces. We are delighted that you'd like to resume your subscription.

title: How to Get Your Luggage Ready-So It's Ready to Travel When You Are
summary: Longing for a journey far away from home? Insider tips on getting your bags ready for takeoff. Plus: what to do when the wheels come off-literally.. Did your frequent-flyer status downgrade to "sofa elite" this last year? With many travel bans still in effect and fewer Americans currently boarding flights, this sabbatical from airports is an ideal opportunity to give languishing luggage some overdue repairs and mileage-extending refurbishments. As travel starts to pick up-Delta's CEO Ed Bastian said on Monday that the company is already reporting an uptick in ticket purchases, and airline stocks are on the rise-you, and your bags, might want to get ready for takeoff.

title: After a Lung Transplant, Liesbeth Stoeffler Ran Marathons
summary: Austrian immigrant started as an au pair in New York and became a vice president at AllianceBernstein. At age 18, Liesbeth Stoeffler moved from her native Austria to New York for an au pair job. Starting with almost no English, she learned computer-graphics skills and worked her way into a position as a vice president at the fund-management firm now known as AllianceBernstein .

title: Number Puzzles (Saturday, March 20)
New Rules to Pull Off March Madness
summary: The NCAA's vast 'controlled environment' protocols aim to stop Covid-19 problems from upending another edition of its lucrative men's basketball tournaments.. More than 2,000 players and coaches had already been subjected to an avalanche of Covid-19 protocols by the time they entered the "controlled environment" the NCAA has erected in Indianapolis for the three weeks of March Madness that begins on Thursday.

title: When the Chelsea Hotel's Doors Were Auctioned Off, These Homeowners Came Knocking
summary: Room doors from the iconic hotel where artists like Bob Dylan, Janis Joplin and Andy Warhol stayed, hit the auction block in 2018. Now they're serving a new purpose for the winning bidders. Bobby Sager thinks in bulk. He amassed 13 units in a luxury Boston high-rise to create for himself a spacious, highly individualized home occupying three floors.

title: Open Doors
summary: The Chelsea display. We are delighted that you'd like to resume your subscription.

title: Tesla, American Outdoor Brands, Coherent: What to Watch When the Stock Market Opens Today
summary: Jobless claims ticked higher during the previous week, surprising economists who expected a drop. Here's what we're watching ahead of Thursday's opening bell.

title: Leslie Wexner to Leave Board of L Brands
summary: Longtime leader of Victoria's Secret and his wife won't stand for re-election after business struggles and controversy over Jeffrey Epstein connection. Leslie Wexner, the longtime leader of L Brands Inc., is leaving the company's board, after struggles at his retail empire and controversy over his relationship with Jeffrey Epstein prompted him to retire as chief executive last year.

title: The Crazy Baseball Team That Lets Fans Catch Foul Balls for Outs
summary: The Savannah Bananas are trying to play two-hour games with a menagerie of wild new rules. If you go: bring your glove.. Baseball games take too long. I'm not saying anything radical here-even baseball agrees with me! With too many nine-inning contests snoozing past the three-hour mark, Major League Baseball continues to tinker with pace-of-play alterations; there are minor league clubs experimenting with 15-second pitch clocks and other tweaks to accelerate the game and spice up the action.

title: Our Teeth Are Getting the Skin-Care Treatment
summary: A pandemic spike in cosmetic dentistry is part Zoom-meeting-influenced, part social media-fueled and part "if not now, then when?," thanks to lots of time for incognito recovery. Inside the surfeit of self-care-for-your-mouth treatments.. Skin isn't the only thing that increased screen time has us zeroing in on. "Zoom has changed the dynamic of how people look at themselves facially in general," says dentist Michael Apa, who has offices in New York, Dubai and Los Angeles. "Looking at yourself in the mirror, you tend to focus more on your skin, but when you're talking, you can't help but see your teeth. Since most people don't talk to themselves in the mirror, this is the first time people are becoming very self-aware of what their teeth look like."

title: Booking a Covid-19 Vaccine? More Tools and Tips, Plus Help From Apple, Facebook and Google
summary: Tech giants join effort to help you search for a vaccine with mapping tools and links; tricks and resources might prove even more helpful. Me: "Hey Siri, refresh the pharmacy websites until there's an available vaccine appointment within 50 miles, then book it as fast as robotically possible. If you can't do that, sound your loudest alarm to get my attention."

title: San Francisco Runs Public School Pods Amid Covid-19 Lockdown Frustrations
summary: Resume Subscription. SAN FRANCISCO-Every morning, as many as 36 children from different public schools gather at the Bernal Heights neighborhood library branch to log in to their online classrooms.

title: Supply Chain Woes Slam Global Manufacturing
summary: Winter storms and crammed ports in the U.S. add to disruptions of production and supplies during the pandemic. Supply chain woes mounted world-wide for makers of everything from cars and clothing to home siding and medical needle containers, as the extreme Texas weather and port backlogs compounded problems for manufacturers already beset by pandemic disruptions.

title: Micron Shows How Chip Making Might Become a National Bloodsport
summary: The memory-chip maker plans to sell its Utah facility, but governments eyeing the production business should take heed of the costs. Perhaps without intending to, Micron has sent a warning to the U.S. government-and others across the world-that getting into the chip-making business isn't for the faint of heart.

title: Bigger May Indeed Be Better for GE's Latest Deal Partner
summary: Post-pandemic aircraft-leasing market will likely be even more favorable to those, like AerCap, able to profit from scale and network effects. In the business of leasing planes to airlines, scale has always played a leading role. The merger of the two biggest players is a bet it will become even more important.

title: A Surge of Children Crossing the Border: What Happens to Them?
summary: A look at the number of migrants arriving illegally in the U.S. and the process for children under the Biden administration. The number of migrants illegally crossing the southern border is reaching a 20-year high, with the number of unaccompanied children increasing 63% last month, according to U.S. Customs and Border Protection.

title: Credit Markets Are Surfing on Waves of Money
summary: Plentiful cash from sources as diverse as SPACs and big banks is helping to drive yields lower in corporate loan markets. Investors seeking yield in corporate loans may be beaten to the punch by loads of cash-even sometimes from special-purpose acquisition companies, or SPACs, and ordinary banks.

title: Sinclair Starts Marketing Push for Its Forthcoming Bally Sports Networks
summary: TV group aims to build a new national sports brand fueled by local coverage. Sinclair Broadcast Group Inc. is preparing to rebrand its regional Fox Sports networks in the U.S. under the banner of Bally Sports, taking the name of casino operator Bally's Corp. as sports media continues to establish closer ties with the gambling industry.

title: Better Trade Policy Could Have Avoided Japan's Beef With American Farmers
summary: The U.S. is disadvantaged both economically and strategically without an alternative to the Trans-Pacific Partnership. American farmers are about to feel a new temporary squeeze, courtesy of the U.S. decision four years ago to abandon membership of the Trans-Pacific Partnership. Rejoining may be politically difficult, but the arguments today are even stronger than when the TPP was originally negotiated.

title: Powell Can't Let Markets See Him Sweat
summary: Keeping low-rate path, Fed chairman appears determined not to signal premature confidence. Headed into Wednesday's Federal Reserve meeting, investors wondered if a brightening outlook would force an earlier increase in interest rates. Officials didn't blink: Their forecasts showed rates wouldn't lift off from near zero before 2024, unchanged from December.

title: Investors Fear Inflation Might Reverse Dollar Gains
summary: A $1.9 trillion spending package and a faster-than-anticipated vaccine rollout are buoying growth forecasts-and inflation. The U.S.'s economic prospects look brighter than those of many other countries-and that has driven an unexpected dollar rally this year.

title: Antibribery Group Urges Slovenia to Step Up Foreign Bribery Enforcement
summary: OECD watchdog says Slovenia has made some progress since its last evaluation about six years ago. Slovenia needs to step up its foreign bribery enforcement and improve detecting such violations, an international antibribery watchdog said.

title: For Doctors in Poor Countries, Covid Vaccine Comes Too Late
summary: As doctors in rich countries get vaccinated, their colleagues in poor countries work unprotected.

title: Stopped Saving for Retirement During the Pandemic? Don't Panic
summary: The impact of temporarily suspending retirement saving-even for a few years-isn't as big as you might think. When it comes to saving for retirement, conventional wisdom calls for starting early and setting aside 10% to 15% of pay annually. But that formula is unrealistic for the millions of workers who take career breaks, including many who have lost jobs over the past year.

title: Texas Grocer H-E-B Is Caught in the Middle of Mask Divide
summary: Firm's messaging shows how lifting the state's face-covering mandate put some businesses in a bind. KERRVILLE, Texas-When Texas Gov. Greg Abbott said he would lift the statewide Covid-19 mask mandate, he left businesses in charge of setting and enforcing their own policies. H-E-B, a beloved Texas grocer and a stalwart during past crises in the state, waffled.

title: Federal Covid-19 Aid Aims to Help Cities, States Avoid Cutting Jobs and Services
summary: Biden administration seeks to avoid prolonged budgetary strain; Republicans say $350 billion is too much. WASHINGTON-The Biden administration has pitched its $1.9 trillion Covid-19 aid package as a way to forestall what it saw as a major risk to the economic recovery: a prolonged budget squeeze for state and local governments. Republicans say much of the aid isn't needed, and at least one GOP lawmaker is urging mayors and governors to give some of it back.

title: U.K. Mulls Capping Number of Audits Big Four Firms Can Do
summary: Government is inviting comment from business and the public on revamping audit regulation in Britain. The U.K. government is seeking feedback on a range of proposals to overhaul the country's audit sector following a series of corporate scandals as well as similar regulatory efforts in Germany.

title: North Korea Gives U.S. Cold Shoulder, Calls Nuclear Talks 'Waste of Time'
summary: Top diplomat says no engagement until U.S. changes its policies toward the Kim Jong Un regime. SEOUL-North Korea sees no reason to return to nuclear talks with the U.S., a top Pyongyang diplomat said, despite multiple efforts by the Biden administration in recent weeks to engage.

title: Tokyo Olympic Official Resigns Over Proposal to Dress Woman as a Pig
summary: Move follows departure of Games chief for sexist remarks, adds uncertainty four months before event. TOKYO-The creative director of the opening and closing ceremonies for the Tokyo Olympics resigned after confirming that he had floated the idea of putting a female celebrity in a pig costume during the opening ceremony.

title: Pepper...and Salt
summary: Resume Subscription. We are delighted that you'd like to resume your subscription.

title: Fed Holds Steady on Interest Rates, Bond Purchases
summary: Most officials expect to hold rates near zero through 2023, while also expecting recovery to gain steam. WASHINGTON-The Federal Reserve kept its easy-money policies in place and vowed to maintain them until the U.S. economy recovers further from the effects of the coronavirus pandemic, while officials also highlighted an improved outlook for growth.

title: Art World Gets Crash Course in NFTs; a Frenzy Ensues
summary: After Beeple's $69 million sale, Christie's remakes its sale categories, Sotheby's is offering digital artworks and accepting Bitcoin and galleries are setting up task forces to study up on crypto-millionaires. It's 'like we just discovered an unknown continent.'. The art market is entering its NFT Period. Last week's $69 million sale of a digital artwork by an artist known as Beeple at Christie's is reverberating through the traditional art world, with top auction houses, galleries and collectors plotting countermoves and taking crash courses.

title: II-VI Makes Revised Bid for Coherent
summary: New bid worth around $285 a share, sources say. II-VI Inc. has submitted a new takeover offer for Coherent Inc. valued at roughly $7 billion, as a frenzied bidding war for the laser maker nears a climax.

title: South Korean Covid-19 Vaccine Developer Surges on Market Debut
summary: Shares of SK Bioscience, which is developing a vaccine to fight new strains, rise 160% from IPO price. A South Korean biotechnology company that is developing a vaccine to fight new strains of Covid-19 jumped on its first day of trading, after concluding Seoul's biggest initial public offering in nearly four years.

title: Man Arrested for Allegedly Carrying Weapon Near Vice President's Residence
summary: Texan charged with weapons offenses after being detained near premises that Harris and her family don't yet inhabit. WASHINGTON-Metropolitan police arrested a man on weapons charges after Secret Service agents detained him outside the grounds of the Naval Observatory, where the official residence of Vice President Kamala Harris and her family is located.

title: Tesla Crash Suspected of Involving Autopilot Draws Probe
summary: Accident is latest seen linked to the electric-car company's driver-assistance feature. U.S. safety regulators are investigating a crash involving a Tesla Inc. vehicle that hit a patrol car in Michigan, the latest in a series of accidents that have heightened regulatory scrutiny of the electric-vehicle maker and its driver-assistance features.

title: Bilibili Eyes $2.8 Billion Hong Kong Share Sale
summary: Video-app operator capitalizing on run-up in shares with plan for secondary listing. Bilibili Inc., the operator of a video app popular with young Chinese videogame and animation fans, is capitalizing on a huge run-up in its shares to raise nearly $3 billion in Hong Kong.

title: Boeing Faces New Hurdle in Delivering Dreamliners
summary: FAA to perform pre-delivery safety checks on some 787 Dreamliners, rather than letting Boeing sign off on new jets, amid tighter regulatory scrutiny. Federal air-safety regulators have stripped Boeing Co. 's authority to inspect and sign off on several newly produced 787 Dreamliners, part of heightened scrutiny of production problems that have halted deliveries of the popular wide-body jets.

title: Tanzania's President John Magufuli, Who Railed Against Mining Companies, Dies at 61
summary: He was nicknamed 'Bulldozer' for his forceful leadership style. John Magufuli, Tanzania's firebrand president who dismissed the severity of the coronavirus pandemic and urged voters to gather in churches and mosques to protect themselves against it, has died, leaving behind a mixed legacy and questions over the leadership of his gold-producing nation. He was 61 years old.

title: New York Gov. Andrew Cuomo's Office Hires Outside Lawyers for Sex-Harassment Probe
summary: Democratic governor faces allegations of sexual harassment and criticism over handling of Covid-19 in nursing homes. New York Gov. Andrew Cuomo's office has hired outside lawyers to represent his Executive Chamber in an investigation into accusations that the governor acted inappropriately to aides in the workplace.
